attributes.title: Changes in inter-personal trust over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic in China
attributes.description:
In the present project, we investigated how the COVID-19 pandemic affected inter-personal trust in a cultural context. We administered an explicit and implicit trustworthiness task to a sample of healthy individuals from China. During both tasks, individuals had to make trustworthiness decisions about other individuals who were either Caucasians or Chinese. However, no information was provided about the trustworthiness of the other individuals. As a consequence, the individuals had to base their trustworthiness decisions on the facial appearance of these individuals. 
As we were interested to learn how the COVID-19 pandemic changed individuals’ trustworthiness decisions, we administered the tasks at different time points of the COVID-19 pandemic. Utilizing a longitudinal and cross-sectional study design, the tasks were administered before the first confirmed cases of the COVID-19 (t0: October 2019 to December 2019) pandemic and after the decline of the COVID-19 pandemic (t1: March 2020). For the cross-sectional study design, we administered the tasks to 100 individuals at t0 and 100 individuals at t1. For the longitudinal study design, we re-administered the tasks at t1 to the 100 individuals that already completed the task at t0. 
It is important to note that COVID-19 pandemic and its impact differed markedly between these time points. Whereas there was an increase in COVID-19 infections from December 2019 to January 2020, there was a decrease in COVID-19 infections from February 2020 to March 2020. However, the dynamic of the COVID-19 pandemic differed between Eastern countries like China and Western countries like Germany. The number of new infections decreased from December 2019 to March 2020 in Eastern countries but the number of new infections in Western countries increased from December 2019 to March 2020. Paralleling this change in infection rates, there was an increase of new infections in China from external visitors to China, including people Western cultures who entered China since February 2020 (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/19/china-reports-no-domestic-cases-of-coronavirus-for-first-time-since-outbreak-began). Media articles reported that as a consequence, there was an increase in prejudices / xenophobia against Western individuals in China since February 2020 (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/29/china-coronavirus-anti-foreigner-feeling-imported-cases). This increase in prejudices may be driven by evolutionary models of disease transmission that state that prejudices constitute a protective mechanism against diseases that are transmitted by unknown and unfamiliar individuals (Neuberg, Kenrick, & Schaller, 2011). Based on these models it can be hypothesized that individuals’ performance on the implicit and explicit trustworthiness tasks towards should change throughout the course of the COVID-19 pandemic. More precisely, it could be expected that the COVID-19 pandemic led to less favorable trustworthiness decisions for Caucasian than Chinese individuals. We, thus, hypothesized that Chinese individuals would display less trust towards Caucasian than Chinese individuals over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic.

q2.value:
We expected that the COVID-19 pandemic led to less favorable trustworthiness decisions for Caucasian than Chinese individuals. This change in favorable trustworthiness decisions should become visible in changes of individuals task performance.
In the implicit task, Chinese individuals should show lower trust ratings for Caucasian individuals than for Chinese individuals. This difference in trustworthy ratings should be more pronounced for individuals with high trustworthy faces than for individuals with low trustworthy faces. Most relevant here, this difference in trustworthy ratings should increase over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic.
In the explicit task, Chinese individuals should show lower money transfers to Caucasian individuals than to Chinese individuals. This difference in trustworthiness-based money transfers should be more pronounced for individuals with high trustworthy than for individuals with low trustworthy faces. Most relevant here, this difference in trustworthiness-based money transfer should increase over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: Blinding is not possible in the current naturalistic design

question.value: The study employed a combined prospective-longitudinal (repeated measurements at T0 and T1) design combined wit the cross-sectional designs (assessment of two independent groups at T1)

q7.value: The current design does not allow randomization

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value:
We registered the project after we collected the data of 100 Chinese individuals at time point t0 (October 2019 to December 2020), which constituted the baseline data for the longitudinal study design and the cross-sectional study design. The collection of this baseline data was already completed at the time of the pre-registration. We additionally collected data of the same 100 Chinese individuals at t1 (March 2020), which constituted the follow-up data for the longitudinal study design. The collection of the follow-up data was still going on at the time of the pre-registration. In addition, we collected data of different 100 Chinese individuals at t1 (March 2020), which constituted the follow-up data for the cross-sectional study design. The collection of this follow-up data was still going on at the time of the pre-registration. 
Of note, we did not analyze the baseline data before we started the collection of the follow-up data and we did not analyze any follow-up data before the completion of the collection of the follow-up data. Most importantly, no data has been analyzed that could be used to test the hypothesis that the COVID-19 pandemic led to less favorable trustworthiness decisions for Caucasian individuals as compared to Chinese individuals. Data collection for T1 is currently ongoing.

question.value: Using public advertisement, we recruited healthy individuals from a student population in China. In order to be included in the study, the individuals had to be aged between 18-35 years, to be well-educated (higher education), to be native speakers and to be of Chinese descent. Individuals who were suffering from mental disorders that required psychotherapeutic or psychopharmacological treatment were excluded from the study. Individuals who participated in the study received a monetary compensation. All data collection procedures were based on an online-system.

q11.value:
For the longitudinal study design, we investigated 100 individuals at time point t0 (October 2019 to December 2020) for the assessment of the baseline data and re-investigated the same 100 individuals at time point t1 (March 2020) for the assessment of the follow-up data. We anticipated a drop-out rate of 25% for the re-investigation of these individuals, implying that we the longitudinal study design was successfully implemented when a minimum of 75 individuals were re-investigated. 
For the cross-sectional study design, we investigated the aforementioned 100 individuals at time point t0 (October 2019 to December 2020) and 100 additional individuals at time point t1 (March 2020).

q12.value:
We performed an a priori power analysis with G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to determine the sample size of the longitudinal and cross-sectional study design. The power analysis indicated that a sample size of 100 individuals for the longitudinal study design and that a sample size of 200 individuals for the cross-sectional study design would be more than sufficient to test our hypotheses that the COVID-19 pandemic led to less favorable trustworthiness decisions for Caucasian as compared to Chinese individuals. The details of the power analysis are provided in the following.
For the longitudinal study design, we performed the power analysis for a repeated measures ANOVA with the within-subject factor time (t0, t1), the within-subject factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). For the cross-sectional study design, we performed the power analysis for a mixed-design ANOVA with the between-subjects factor time (t0, t1), the within-subjects factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). For both study designs, the power analysis focused on medium-sized interaction effects between the factors time, facial trustworthiness and ethnicity that should be detected with sufficient power on a conventional significance value (f2 = .25, 1-β = .80, α = .05).

q13.value: For both study designs, data collection will be stopped after reaching the a priori defined number of participants.

question.value: We performed a naturalistic study that capitalized on the dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemics and its societal and medical impact in China. For this reason, we did not use experimental methods to manipulate any variable that was collected throughout the study.

We used implicit and explicit trustworthiness tasks, namely a trustworthiness rating and trust game, that had been successfully employed in previous studies on inter-personal trust in cultural contexts (Stanley, Sokol-Hessner, Banaji, & Phelps, 2011). For the implicit trustworthiness task, individuals had to rate the trustworthiness of Chinese or Caucasian individuals. No information was provided about the Chinese and Caucasian individuals, meaning that the individuals had to base their trustworthiness ratings on the faces of these individuals. Individuals were instructed to rely on their gut feelings and to apply the ratings as fast as possible using a Likert scale that ranged from 1 (untrustworthy) to 9 (trustworthy). These ratings constituted the outcome measures that were used for the statistical analysis.
For the explicit trustworthiness task, individuals had to indicate how much money they were willing to transfer to Chinese or Caucasian individuals for investment reasons. These individuals could either re-transfer a proportion of the invested money in which case the money would be tripled before the re-transfer or keep the invested money in which case the money would not be re-transferred. No information was provided about the Chinese and Caucasian individuals, meaning that the individuals had to base their trustworthiness-based money transfers on the faces of these individuals. Individuals were instructed to rely on their gut feelings and to perform the transfers as fast as possible using a Likert scale that ranged from 1 (0 RMB) to 6 (10 RMB). These ratings constituted the outcome measures that were used for the statistical analysis.
The faces that we used in the implicit and explicit trustworthiness tasks had been selected from a pool of faces showing neutral expressions. Following an established procedure (Lischke, Junge, Hamm, & Weymar, 2018; Wendt, Weymar, Junge, Hamm, & Lischke, 2019; Weymar, Ventura-Bort, Wendt, & Lischke, 2019), the faces were pre-selected by independent raters and evaluated by independent samples of healthy individuals. As a consequence, faces were obtained that showed no emotional expression but varied subtly in trustworthiness. More precisely, 24 faces of Caucasian individuals that were either high (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) or low (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) in trustworthiness and 24 faces of Chinese individuals that were either high (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) or low (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) in trustworthiness were used for the implicit and explicit trustworthiness tasks.

We used individuals’ trustworthiness ratings as the outcome measure of the implicit trustworthiness task and individuals’ trustworthiness-related money transfers as the outcome measure of the explicit trustworthiness tasks. These outcome measures were used for the statistical analyses.

To analyze the outcome measures of the longitudinal study design, we performed a repeated measures ANOVA with the within-subject factor time (t0, t1), the within-subject factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). To decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness and ethnicity and to decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness, ethnicity and time, planned comparisons were performed. 
To analyze the outcome measures of the cross-sectional study design, we performed a mixed-design ANOVA with the between-subjects factor time (t0, t1), the within-subjects factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). To decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness and ethnicity and to decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness, ethnicity and time, planned comparisons were performed. To analyze the outcome measures of the longitudinal and cross-sectional study design in an exploratory manner, we considered individuals’ sex as an additional factor in the respective repeated measures and mixed design ANOVAs and decomposed the interaction effects of the respective repeated measures and mixed design ANOVAs with t-tests.

q18.value: We performed no transformations of the outcome measures of the longitudinal and cross-sectional study design.

q19.value: p-values of <.05 will be considered as significant

q20.value: We will exclude participants from the analyses whose data represented outliers. Outliers were determined on basis of boxplots and interquartile ranges.

q21.value: We excluded participants with missing data from the analyses.

q22.value: Variations in significant trustworthiness differences and associations between relevant personality factors will be examined.

registration_responses.q2:
We expected that the COVID-19 pandemic led to less favorable trustworthiness decisions for Caucasian than Chinese individuals. This change in favorable trustworthiness decisions should become visible in changes of individuals task performance.
In the implicit task, Chinese individuals should show lower trust ratings for Caucasian individuals than for Chinese individuals. This difference in trustworthy ratings should be more pronounced for individuals with high trustworthy faces than for individuals with low trustworthy faces. Most relevant here, this difference in trustworthy ratings should increase over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic.
In the explicit task, Chinese individuals should show lower money transfers to Caucasian individuals than to Chinese individuals. This difference in trustworthiness-based money transfers should be more pronounced for individuals with high trustworthy than for individuals with low trustworthy faces. Most relevant here, this difference in trustworthiness-based money transfer should increase over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic.

q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q7: The current design does not allow randomization
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q9:
We registered the project after we collected the data of 100 Chinese individuals at time point t0 (October 2019 to December 2020), which constituted the baseline data for the longitudinal study design and the cross-sectional study design. The collection of this baseline data was already completed at the time of the pre-registration. We additionally collected data of the same 100 Chinese individuals at t1 (March 2020), which constituted the follow-up data for the longitudinal study design. The collection of the follow-up data was still going on at the time of the pre-registration. In addition, we collected data of different 100 Chinese individuals at t1 (March 2020), which constituted the follow-up data for the cross-sectional study design. The collection of this follow-up data was still going on at the time of the pre-registration. 
Of note, we did not analyze the baseline data before we started the collection of the follow-up data and we did not analyze any follow-up data before the completion of the collection of the follow-up data. Most importantly, no data has been analyzed that could be used to test the hypothesis that the COVID-19 pandemic led to less favorable trustworthiness decisions for Caucasian individuals as compared to Chinese individuals. Data collection for T1 is currently ongoing.
registration_responses.q11:
For the longitudinal study design, we investigated 100 individuals at time point t0 (October 2019 to December 2020) for the assessment of the baseline data and re-investigated the same 100 individuals at time point t1 (March 2020) for the assessment of the follow-up data. We anticipated a drop-out rate of 25% for the re-investigation of these individuals, implying that we the longitudinal study design was successfully implemented when a minimum of 75 individuals were re-investigated. 
For the cross-sectional study design, we investigated the aforementioned 100 individuals at time point t0 (October 2019 to December 2020) and 100 additional individuals at time point t1 (March 2020).
registration_responses.q12:
We performed an a priori power analysis with G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to determine the sample size of the longitudinal and cross-sectional study design. The power analysis indicated that a sample size of 100 individuals for the longitudinal study design and that a sample size of 200 individuals for the cross-sectional study design would be more than sufficient to test our hypotheses that the COVID-19 pandemic led to less favorable trustworthiness decisions for Caucasian as compared to Chinese individuals. The details of the power analysis are provided in the following.
For the longitudinal study design, we performed the power analysis for a repeated measures ANOVA with the within-subject factor time (t0, t1), the within-subject factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). For the cross-sectional study design, we performed the power analysis for a mixed-design ANOVA with the between-subjects factor time (t0, t1), the within-subjects factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). For both study designs, the power analysis focused on medium-sized interaction effects between the factors time, facial trustworthiness and ethnicity that should be detected with sufficient power on a conventional significance value (f2 = .25, 1-β = .80, α = .05).
registration_responses.q13: For both study designs, data collection will be stopped after reaching the a priori defined number of participants.
registration_responses.q18: We performed no transformations of the outcome measures of the longitudinal and cross-sectional study design.
registration_responses.q19: p-values of <.05 will be considered as significant
registration_responses.q20: We will exclude participants from the analyses whose data represented outliers. Outliers were determined on basis of boxplots and interquartile ranges.
registration_responses.q21: We excluded participants with missing data from the analyses.
registration_responses.q22: Variations in significant trustworthiness differences and associations between relevant personality factors will be examined.
registration_responses.q6.question: The study employed a combined prospective-longitudinal (repeated measurements at T0 and T1) design combined wit the cross-sectional designs (assessment of two independent groups at T1)
registration_responses.q10.question: Using public advertisement, we recruited healthy individuals from a student population in China. In order to be included in the study, the individuals had to be aged between 18-35 years, to be well-educated (higher education), to be native speakers and to be of Chinese descent. Individuals who were suffering from mental disorders that required psychotherapeutic or psychopharmacological treatment were excluded from the study. Individuals who participated in the study received a monetary compensation. All data collection procedures were based on an online-system.
registration_responses.q14.question: We performed a naturalistic study that capitalized on the dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemics and its societal and medical impact in China. For this reason, we did not use experimental methods to manipulate any variable that was collected throughout the study.
registration_responses.q15.question:
We used implicit and explicit trustworthiness tasks, namely a trustworthiness rating and trust game, that had been successfully employed in previous studies on inter-personal trust in cultural contexts (Stanley, Sokol-Hessner, Banaji, & Phelps, 2011). For the implicit trustworthiness task, individuals had to rate the trustworthiness of Chinese or Caucasian individuals. No information was provided about the Chinese and Caucasian individuals, meaning that the individuals had to base their trustworthiness ratings on the faces of these individuals. Individuals were instructed to rely on their gut feelings and to apply the ratings as fast as possible using a Likert scale that ranged from 1 (untrustworthy) to 9 (trustworthy). These ratings constituted the outcome measures that were used for the statistical analysis.
For the explicit trustworthiness task, individuals had to indicate how much money they were willing to transfer to Chinese or Caucasian individuals for investment reasons. These individuals could either re-transfer a proportion of the invested money in which case the money would be tripled before the re-transfer or keep the invested money in which case the money would not be re-transferred. No information was provided about the Chinese and Caucasian individuals, meaning that the individuals had to base their trustworthiness-based money transfers on the faces of these individuals. Individuals were instructed to rely on their gut feelings and to perform the transfers as fast as possible using a Likert scale that ranged from 1 (0 RMB) to 6 (10 RMB). These ratings constituted the outcome measures that were used for the statistical analysis.
The faces that we used in the implicit and explicit trustworthiness tasks had been selected from a pool of faces showing neutral expressions. Following an established procedure (Lischke, Junge, Hamm, & Weymar, 2018; Wendt, Weymar, Junge, Hamm, & Lischke, 2019; Weymar, Ventura-Bort, Wendt, & Lischke, 2019), the faces were pre-selected by independent raters and evaluated by independent samples of healthy individuals. As a consequence, faces were obtained that showed no emotional expression but varied subtly in trustworthiness. More precisely, 24 faces of Caucasian individuals that were either high (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) or low (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) in trustworthiness and 24 faces of Chinese individuals that were either high (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) or low (12 individuals, 6 males and 6 females) in trustworthiness were used for the implicit and explicit trustworthiness tasks.
registration_responses.q16.question: We used individuals’ trustworthiness ratings as the outcome measure of the implicit trustworthiness task and individuals’ trustworthiness-related money transfers as the outcome measure of the explicit trustworthiness tasks. These outcome measures were used for the statistical analyses.
registration_responses.q17.question:
To analyze the outcome measures of the longitudinal study design, we performed a repeated measures ANOVA with the within-subject factor time (t0, t1), the within-subject factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). To decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness and ethnicity and to decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness, ethnicity and time, planned comparisons were performed. 
To analyze the outcome measures of the cross-sectional study design, we performed a mixed-design ANOVA with the between-subjects factor time (t0, t1), the within-subjects factor facial trustworthiness (high, low) and the within-subject factor ethnicity (Caucasian, Chinese). To decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness and ethnicity and to decompose the interaction between the factors facial trustworthiness, ethnicity and time, planned comparisons were performed. To analyze the outcome measures of the longitudinal and cross-sectional study design in an exploratory manner, we considered individuals’ sex as an additional factor in the respective repeated measures and mixed design ANOVAs and decomposed the interaction effects of the respective repeated measures and mixed design ANOVAs with t-tests.

attributes.title: Ingroup Identification, Content of Social Contact, & Intergroup Inequality
attributes.description: The current study is the first phase of my dissertation. I aim to examine the effect of the content of social contact on advantaged group members' attitudes and behaviors towards disadvantaged ones in the context of intergroup inequality.

q2.value:
1. Turks who are advantaged group members who perceive that they have more similar aspects with Syrians who are disadvantaged group members will perceive the social system between them as less unequal than Turks who perceive that they have more different aspects with Syrians.

2. Turks who perceive that they have more similar aspects with Syrians will perceive that their ingroup is fairer than Turks who perceive that they have more different aspects with Syrians.

3a. There will be no difference between groups in terms of supporting a social policy (H+S+) that provides advantages for both groups.

3b. Turks who perceive that they have more different aspects with Syrians will show greater support to the social policies that provide (a) neutral for Host and advantageous for Syrians (HnS+), (b) advantageous for Host and disadvantageous for Syrians (H+S-), and (c) disadvantageous for Host and advantageous for Syrians (H-S+).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: Confederate workers will not know about hypotheses.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (the content of social contact) and 2 levels (commonality induce and difference induce).

q7.value: I will use simple randomization, where a participant will be randomly assigned to either commonality or difference conditions. These two conditions will be equally sized. Randomization will be done with Qualtrics' randomization function.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through the Sona System of my department and social media accounts of my department. Student participants who meet the specifications will receive 2 bonus points. Non-students will receive 20 Turkish Liras. The incentive will be raised up to 50 Turkish Liras if the sample size is not reached at the planned time. 

Since I aim to reach a representative Turkish sample, I synthesized the demographic statistic documents of the Turkish Statistical Institute and the 2012-2014 World Value Survey of Turkey. All tables and data I used are attached as an Excel document. The final version that shows a-priori characteristics of the required sample is attached as a Word document.

q11.value: I plan to reach approximately 200 participants assuming that my manipulation will not work for all participants. My target sample size is 150.

q12.value:
I used G*Power to conduct a power analysis. I will run two one-way ANOVA, and one MANOVA with five outcomes. Firstly, to obtain effect size f, I explored previous studies that used the same or similar independents and outcomes. The most current research was Saguy & Chernyaik-Hai (2012, Study 1). I used partial-eta squared of one-way ANOVA that analyzes the association between content of contact type and perception of the hierarchy as legitimate because the most similar variables are these. First, I pretended that the partial eta-square was like an eta-square since the researchers did not report eta-square. To use this parameter in G-Power, I converted it to "effect size f" with using https://www.psychometrica.de/effect_size.html. The value is .3693. Second, because I will run two one-way ANOVA with per one outcome, I divided alpha to two. Third, I choose power as .92 to be more conservative. Finally, the required sample size is 100. 

I repeated this process for MANOVA. Because there are no studies that analyze the association between the same or similar independent and outcomes, I chose an effect size that is between medium and high, as .123.  Finally, the required sample size is 150. 

In conclusion, I need to observe a minimum of 150 participants' valid behavior. The protocols of G*Power are attached as a Word document.

q13.value: If I find it difficult to reach my participants with certain characteristics, for instance, if I discern that I cannot finish collecting data within 3 months after starting, I will collect data from those I can reach.

question.value: I will manipulate the content of social contact with two levels that highlight commonality or difference between advantaged and disadvantaged groups.

1) Unequal Social System Perception 
2) Ingroup Fairness

3) Supporting different types of social policies. 

Social policies will highlight the following types;

a) It provides an advantage for both Host and Syrians (H+S+)
b) It provides an advantage for only Syrians (HnS+)
c) It  provides an advantage for Host, but a disadvantage for Syrians (H+S-)
d) It provides a disadvantage for Host, but an advantage for Syrians (H-S+)

The perception of unequal social system between groups and ingroup fairness will constitute the attitude aspect of inequality between groups. In other words, the mean of these two scales will create the attitude aspect of inequality between groups.

Social policies with five indicators (four of them mentioned above and the last one is total score) will constitute the behavior aspect of inequality between groups.

I will run one-way ANOVA for two outcomes which are the perception of unequal social system and ingroup fairness.

I will run a MANOVA with five indicators of supporting social policies.

All analyses will run with R, Jamovi, or JASP.

q20.value: The data of participants who leave measurements of dependents, age, sex, the region where live, religiosity, and level of education empty will be excluded. I will verify that no data will be excluded except this situation, including outliers.

q21.value: The data of participants who leave measurements of dependents, age, sex, the region where live, religiosity, and level of education empty will be excluded. I will verify that no data will be created with the mean of series or no such methods will be used.

q23.value: The manipulation is adapted from Saguy & Chernyak-Hai, 2012, study 1. Also, dependent measurements except supporting social policies are adapted from Saguy's several studies that investigate the "irony of harmony".

attributes.title: Cultural Distance and Democracy
attributes.description: Building on a MSc thesis at the London School of Economics we attempt to predict outcomes of democracy.

q2.value:
We test the following hypotheses:
1.	Cultural distances between more highly educated, wealthier social classes between countries is smaller than cultural distances between lower educated, poorer social classes between countries. We have run preliminary analyses as part of a Masters dissertation testing this hypothesis, but will be conducting follow up studies. This MSc thesis is attached.
2.	The degree of cultural distance between high and low education and between rich and poorer social classes within a country is positively correlated with measures of inequality and corruption, and negatively correlated with measures of social mobility and the success of democracy. 

Please refer to our Pre-registration document for more details.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Based on the methodology outlined by Muthukrishna et al. (2020), we first create a measure that allows us to measure the cultural distances between and within social classes across countries. We use the same variables as Muthukrishna et al. (2020) and use the last two waves (5&6) of the World Value Survey as data. We split this dataset along three dimensions: 
1.	Educational level recoded (X025R in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents classified as “Upper” will be considered high education. Respondents classified as “Lower” will be considered low education.
2.	Subjective Social Status as stated by the responded (X045 in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents who responded “Upper class” or “Upper middle class” will be considered high social status. Respondents who responded “Working class” or “Lower class” will be considered low social status.
3.	Subjective income percentile as stated by the respondent (X047 in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents in the 8th, 9th, and 10th step will be considered high income. Respondents in the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd step will be considered low income. 
Following this CFst scores as described by Muthukrishna et al. (2020) will be computed for each dimension separately. See Muthukrishna et al. (2020) for the CFst methodology. Scores for each dimension will be computed for three conditions: 
1.	Distances between each pair of high-high conditions across countries
2.	Distances between each pair of low-low conditions across countries
3.	Distances between the high and the low condition within each country
For completeness and as a comparison, we will also look at the distance between the pair of high-high conditions across countries.
These scores thereby serve as our main explanatory variables. 
We will then conduct the following analyses:
1.	Check whether cultural distances between and within social classes are significantly larger across than within countries. 
2.	Employ a multivariate regression to assess to what degree our cultural distance variables within countries predict our five outcome variable measures. 
We will conduct analysis 2) with and without the following controls from the V-Dem Version 10 dataset, computing the difference between countries (Coppedge et al., 2019): 
1.	GDP per capita (e_migdppc)
2.	Years of education for citizens older than 15 (e_peaveduc) 
3.	National population size (e_wb_pop) 
4.	Region or Continent (e_regiongeo; since many regions are very small, we will also recode into continents. Continent will be considered our primary clustering unit for the purposes of the multilevel model. We will also include as fixed effects to test for robustness) 

Please refer to our Pre-registration document and the corresponding MSC thesis ("22891")for more details.

q11.value:
Waves 5&6 of the World Value Survey which constitute the basis of our analysis combine the responses of more than 170,000 participants from 80 countries. 
Polity IV (2018) scores are available for 167 countries, of which only the ones matching our initial dataset of 80 countries are used. 
Fragile State Index (2019) scores are available for 178 countries, of which only the ones matching our initial dataset of 80 countries are used. 
Liberal democracy index scores are available for 202 countries. 
2018 Corruption Perceptions Index scores, 180 observations are available, of which only matching ones are used. 
Gini Coefficient 160 observations are available, of which only matching ones are used.  
GDMI include data for 148 economies, of which only matching ones are used. 

Please refer to our Pre-registration document and the corresponding MSC thesis ("22891")for more details.

1.	Educational level recoded (X025R in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents classified as “Upper” will be considered high education. Respondents classified as “Lower” will be considered low education.
2.	Subjective Social Status as stated by the responded (X045 in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents who responded “Upper class” or “Upper middle class” will be considered high social status. Respondents who responded “Working class” or “Lower class” will be considered low social status.

Following this CFst scores as described by Muthukrishna et al. (2020) will be computed for each dimension separately. See Muthukrishna et al. (2020) for the CFst methodology. Scores for each dimension will be computed for three conditions: 
1.	Distances between each pair of high-high conditions across countries
2.	Distances between each pair of low-low conditions across countries
3.	Distances between the high and the low condition within each country
For completeness and as a comparison, we will also look at the distance between the pair of high-high conditions across countries.
These scores thereby serve as our main explanatory variables.

1.	Check whether cultural distances between and within social classes are significantly larger across than within countries. 
2.	Employ a multivariate regression to assess to what degree our cultural distance variables within countries predict our five outcome variable measures. 
We will conduct analysis 2) with and without the following controls from the V-Dem Version 10 dataset, computing the difference between countries (Coppedge et al., 2019): 
1.	GDP per capita (e_migdppc)
2.	Years of education for citizens older than 15 (e_peaveduc) 
3.	National population size (e_wb_pop) 
4.	Region or Continent (e_regiongeo; since many regions are very small, we will also recode into continents. Continent will be considered our primary clustering unit for the purposes of the multilevel model. We will also include as fixed effects to test for robustness) 

The dependent variables of this study will be established measures of inequality, social mobility, corruption and democracy. 
Democracy will be measured using three separate measures: 
1.	The most recent Polity IV (2018) scores from the polity project 
2.	The most recent Fragile State Index (2019) scores from the Fund for Peace 
3.	Most recent scores from the Liberal democracy index from the V-Dem institute (2019). 
Corruption will be measured using the 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI 2019). 
Inequality will be measured using the Gini Coefficient provided by the World Bank (2019). 
Social mobility will be based on the global database on intergenerational mobility (GDIM) by Narayan et al. (2018).
Please refer to our Pre-registration document and the corresponding MSC thesis ("22891")for more details.

Polity IV (2018) scores are available for 167 countries, of which only the ones matching our initial dataset of 80 countries are used. 
Fragile State Index (2019) scores are available for 178 countries, of which only the ones matching our initial dataset of 80 countries are used. 
Liberal democracy index scores are available for 202 countries. 
2018 Corruption Perceptions Index scores, 180 observations are available, of which only matching ones are used. 
Gini Coefficient 160 observations are available, of which only matching ones are used.  
GDMI include data for 148 economies, of which only matching ones are used. 

Please refer to our Pre-registration document and the corresponding MSC thesis ("22891")for more details.

registration_responses.q6.question:
Based on the methodology outlined by Muthukrishna et al. (2020), we first create a measure that allows us to measure the cultural distances between and within social classes across countries. We use the same variables as Muthukrishna et al. (2020) and use the last two waves (5&6) of the World Value Survey as data. We split this dataset along three dimensions: 
1.	Educational level recoded (X025R in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents classified as “Upper” will be considered high education. Respondents classified as “Lower” will be considered low education.
2.	Subjective Social Status as stated by the responded (X045 in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents who responded “Upper class” or “Upper middle class” will be considered high social status. Respondents who responded “Working class” or “Lower class” will be considered low social status.
3.	Subjective income percentile as stated by the respondent (X047 in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents in the 8th, 9th, and 10th step will be considered high income. Respondents in the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd step will be considered low income. 
Following this CFst scores as described by Muthukrishna et al. (2020) will be computed for each dimension separately. See Muthukrishna et al. (2020) for the CFst methodology. Scores for each dimension will be computed for three conditions: 
1.	Distances between each pair of high-high conditions across countries
2.	Distances between each pair of low-low conditions across countries
3.	Distances between the high and the low condition within each country
For completeness and as a comparison, we will also look at the distance between the pair of high-high conditions across countries.
These scores thereby serve as our main explanatory variables. 
We will then conduct the following analyses:
1.	Check whether cultural distances between and within social classes are significantly larger across than within countries. 
2.	Employ a multivariate regression to assess to what degree our cultural distance variables within countries predict our five outcome variable measures. 
We will conduct analysis 2) with and without the following controls from the V-Dem Version 10 dataset, computing the difference between countries (Coppedge et al., 2019): 
1.	GDP per capita (e_migdppc)
2.	Years of education for citizens older than 15 (e_peaveduc) 
3.	National population size (e_wb_pop) 
4.	Region or Continent (e_regiongeo; since many regions are very small, we will also recode into continents. Continent will be considered our primary clustering unit for the purposes of the multilevel model. We will also include as fixed effects to test for robustness) 

Please refer to our Pre-registration document and the corresponding MSC thesis ("22891")for more details.
registration_responses.q10.question: Secondary Analysis: Preexisting data is used.

3.	Subjective income percentile as stated by the respondent (X047 in Longitudinal WVS dataset). Respondents in the 8th, 9th, and 10th step will be considered high income. Respondents in the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd step will be considered low income. 
Following this CFst scores as described by Muthukrishna et al. (2020) will be computed for each dimension separately. See Muthukrishna et al. (2020) for the CFst methodology. Scores for each dimension will be computed for three conditions: 
1.	Distances between each pair of high-high conditions across countries
2.	Distances between each pair of low-low conditions across countries
3.	Distances between the high and the low condition within each country
For completeness and as a comparison, we will also look at the distance between the pair of high-high conditions across countries.
These scores thereby serve as our main explanatory variables. 
We will then conduct the following analyses:
1.	Check whether cultural distances between and within social classes are significantly larger across than within countries. 
2.	Employ a multivariate regression to assess to what degree our cultural distance variables within countries predict our five outcome variable measures. 
We will conduct analysis 2) with and without the following controls from the V-Dem Version 10 dataset, computing the difference between countries (Coppedge et al., 2019): 
1.	GDP per capita (e_migdppc)
2.	Years of education for citizens older than 15 (e_peaveduc) 
3.	National population size (e_wb_pop) 
4.	Region or Continent (e_regiongeo; since many regions are very small, we will also recode into continents. Continent will be considered our primary clustering unit for the purposes of the multilevel model. We will also include as fixed effects to test for robustness) 

The dependent variables of this study will be established measures of inequality, social mobility, corruption and democracy. 
Democracy will be measured using three separate measures: 
1.	The most recent Polity IV (2018) scores from the polity project 
2.	The most recent Fragile State Index (2019) scores from the Fund for Peace 
3.	Most recent scores from the Liberal democracy index from the V-Dem institute (2019). 
Corruption will be measured using the 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI 2019). 
Inequality will be measured using the Gini Coefficient provided by the World Bank (2019). 
Social mobility will be based on the global database on intergenerational mobility (GDIM) by Narayan et al. (2018).

attributes.title: Twitter Friend Selection and Mental Health
attributes.description: Current mental health as a predictor of which Twitter accounts participants choose to follow

q1.value: Twitter Friend Selection and Mental Health

q3.value:
The last decade has seen explosive growth of online social networks, which are now a pervasive part of everyday life for many people. As such, it is important to understand the relationship between social media and mental health. Previous research has documented a variety of relationships between psychological characteristics and online behaviors. For example, it has found that positive and negative emotions are related to self-expression online. Additionally, personality traits are correlated with word use and patterns of “likes” in Facebook and with word use and network structure on Twitter. 

Although previous work in this area has been promising, social media studies to date often rely on outward facing behaviors such as public posts or “likes” which are subject to self-monitoring or a public persona. Instead, we will use Twitter friends (the accounts one chooses to follow) as a behavioral measure that is less publicly highlighted on the platform and therefore, less subject to self-monitoring. We will use this behavioral data, as well as, self-reports of personality and mental health characteristics to better understand the relationship between mental health and social media usage. Specifically, we will examine if current mental health predicts which Twitter accounts participants choose to follow. This research will help us better understand how mental health and personality shape people’s online experiences.

q4.value: We hypothesize that current mental health will predict which Twitter accounts participants choose to follow. We will do this with an a priori scoring system and also with a data driven predictive modeling approach.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: We will do a blind screening to look for anomalous responding (see more details in data exclusion)

question.value: Cross-sectional study design

q9.value: All participants will see the same set of 100 Twitter profile screenshots, but the order in which they are displayed will be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will complete a survey with the Big Five Inventory (BFI-2), a supplemental set of Honesty/Propriety items written in the same format as the BFI items, the Scale of Positive and Negative Experience (SPANE), the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS), the PROMIS Depression, Anger, and Anxiety scales, and the Trauma Symptom Questionnaire. Participants will then be shown screenshots of 100 Twitter profiles and asked how interested they are in following that account. Finally, participants will provide their Twitter usernames, answer questions about their social media usage, and complete a demographic questionnaire.

Participants will access the survey through a set of available studies on SONA, the online experiment signup system for the University of Oregon Psychology-Linguistics subject pool. They will take the survey on the Qualtrics survey on their own computer at a time of their choosing.  Participation will take approximately 30 minutes and participants will be compensated with course credit for their introductory psychology or linguistics course. We will include participants that are active Twitter users, have a public Twitter profile, and follow at least 25 Twitter accounts.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 300 participants. If the academic terms ends before we reach that limit, we will end the study.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a sensitivity power analysis. With a sample of 300  and .05 error probability we will have .95 power to detect a correlation of .2, the average effect size in social psychology.

question.value: We will measure participants' personality traits (Big Five plus Honesty/Propriety), anxiety, depression, anger, PTSD, positive feelings, negative feelings, satisfaction with life, demographic variables, self-report of Twitter usage, and interest in following a set of 100 Twitter accounts. Attached are the questions that make up each measured variable.

To score each scale, necessary questions will be reverse-scored and the mean will be calculated.

We will calculate a variable of general pathology by z-scoring the PROMIS Depression, Anger, and Anxiety scales, and the Trauma Symptom Questionnaire and taking an average of the four scales. 

The 100 Twitter profiles used in the questionnaire were the 50 highest correlates and 50 lowest correlates with a general pathology measure from a previous study (Costello et. al, 2020). For our study, participant interest in an individual Twitter account is measured by asking participants 'How interested are you in following this account' (on a scale of 1-4, 1 being 'not at all', 4 being 'very'), they are also able to skip the profile without providing a response (0). To calculate participant's average interest in the set of accounts, responses to the 50 lowest correlate accounts will be reverse scored and then the average will be taken across responses to all 100 Twitter accounts.

We will use OLS regression, regressing general pathology on Twitter account interest. We will repeat this analysis with contrast codes of gender, race, and ethnicity.  

We will also do data-driven predictive modeling, using Twitter account interest to predict general pathology. We will compare the modeling techniques of random forest and principal components regression, considering both predictive accuracy and interpretability in choosing a best model. For these models our data will be split 2/3 in a training set and 1/3 in a test set. 

We will repeat the above analyses examining, in separate models, each of the following in relation to interest in our set of Twitter accounts: personality traits (Big Five plus Honesty/Propriety), positive feelings, negative feelings, and satisfaction with life.

q22.value: We will do a blind screening to look for anomalous responding. The data will be divided into two separate sets, one for the Twitter friend selection task and one for all other survey questions, and the order of each dataset will be scrambled. A blind analyst will look through each dataset to detect anomalous patterns in the data to mark for exclusion.

q23.value:
For the Twitter friend selection task, if less than 10% of responses are missing, those responses will be dropped from our analyses. If more than 10% of responses are missing, we will treat the entire scale as missing. 

For the self-report measures, if less than 20% of responses are missing, those responses will be dropped from our analyses. If more than 20% of responses are missing, we will treat the entire scale as missing.

attributes.title: Implications of the Dialectical Self for Personal Well-Being and Interpersonal Relationships
attributes.description: The dialectical self has been linked to low personal well-being, but positive functions of the dialectical self for interpersonal relationships have rarely been investigated. This study examined the relations of the dialectical self to both personal well-being and interpersonal relationships, along with hypothesized mediators of these relations: self-concept control, self-concept consistency, and self-insight.

q2.value:
Directional hypothesis 1) We hypothesize that self-concept control and self-concept consistency would serially mediate the relation between the dialectical self and individual well-being. 

Directional hypothesis 2) We expect that participants’ self-insight (i.e. profile correltation between the personality ratings by the self and his/her friend) about their negative attributes would mediate the relation between the dialectical self and friends’ liking of the self.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our study is a correlational study. Hypothesized models are attached below.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value:
Our study is divided into two phases. We will collect self-evaluations from participants in Phase 1, and in Phase 2 we will ask their friends to evaluate the Phase 1 participants on the same dimensions. 

It should be noted that the Phase 2 dataset will be merged with an existing dataset that has not been assessed by the investigator. Because the response rate for Phase 2 may be problematic, we plan to merge this new dataset with an existing one to increase the power.

question.value: We will recruit participants from a Midwestern university student pool. Participants will have to be 18 or older in order for them to be able to take in part. We will ask participants in Phase 1 to provide two email addresses of their friends. Participants will be compensated with study credits. Friends of the participants will receive a brief survey pertaining to the personality of the participant. Friends of the participants would also have to be 18 or older to be able to participate. Friends of participants will not receive any compensation, but their emails will be entered into a drawing for one $25 Amazon gift card.

q12.value: We conducted a power analysis using the Monte Carlo simulation method in Mplus software. The power analysis was based on the model for hypothesis 1 and the parameters acquired through a previous study we conducted. The results indicated that we need 320 samples to get the power of 0.8 for detecting indirect effects of interest, with an alpha of 0.05.

question.value: Not applicable

Outcome measures:

1. Self-esteem ( Self-Esteem Inventory; Rosenberg, 1965)
2. Depression (The Center for Epidemiological Studies–Depression Scale (CES-D; Radloff, 1977)
3. Liking by friends: Measured with several items including "How much do you like this friend?"

Predictor variables

1. DIalectical self (Dialectical Self Scale; Spencer-Rodgers et al., 2015)
2. Self-concept consistency (Ten Item Personality Measure (TIPI; Gosling et al., 2003); TIPI for the self as a university student, the self at social gatherings, and the self around one's family
3. Self-concept control (adapted from McConnell, 2005). Three items pertaining to each or their self-concepts specified above (e.g., (“How much control do you have over your self-concept as a university student?”, “What is the extent to which your self-concept as a university student is self-initiated?”, “How stable is your self-concept as a university student?”).
4. California Q-sort - negative items (Block, 2008); 40 items out of 100, based on professionals' ratings

Self-esteem: responses to the whole scale will be averaged 
Depression: responses to the whole scale will be averaged 
Dialectical self: responses to the whole scale will be averaged 
Self-concept control: responses to the whole scale will be averaged 
Self-concept consistency: The self-consistency score will be computed by conducting a factor analysis of the attributes for each individual across all three roles. 
Negative self-insight: Profile correlation and distinct profile correlation scores will be computed to come up with indices for negative self-insight
Liking by friends: responses to the whole scale will be averaged

We will conduct two serial mediation analyses for hypothesis 1. We will examine self-concept control and self-concept consistency as serial mediators of the relation between the dialectical self and well-being measures: depression, and self-esteem. We will use PROCESS macro Ver. 3.3 for SPSS (Hayes, 2017) to conduct mediation analyses. 

We will use the same program to analyze the result for hypothesis 2. We will examine if self-insight into negative attributes was a significant mediator of the relation between the dialectical self and liking by friends.

q19.value: We will use the confidence interval to examine the significance of results; if the interval does not include 0, we'll consider the result to be significant

q20.value: We will exclude any responses that provide incorrect answers for the awareness check. We will report the frequencies of each of these cases of exclusion in the manuscript.

q21.value: If there is any missing data among the participants who will be taken into analysis, we will simply treat that data as missing; no imputations will be made. Participants in our survey were allowed to pass the questions if they did not want to respond for any reason.

q22.value: No additional exploratory analysis is planned other than those mentioned in the Statistical models section above.

We will use the same program to analyze the result for hypothesis 2. We will examine if self-insight into negative attributes was a significant mediator of the relation between the dialectical self and liking by friends.

question.value: Searches will be conducted on MEDLINE, EMBASE and COCHRANE without language or date restriction in April 2020. Descriptors will be related to “low back pain”, “study design” and “older people”. Detailed search strategy is presented in Appendix 1. In addition, we will hand search previous reviews in the area for potential full texts not identified in our searches.

q12.value: However, there is a need for a systematic review of high methodological quality to investigate prognosis of pain, disability, falls, quality of life and coping in older people with non-specific LBP

question.value: Pain, disability, quality of life, coping and falls.

Pain (i.e. Visual Analogue Scale or Numeric Pain Rating Scale), disability (i.e. Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire or Oswestry Disability Questionnaire), quality of life (i.e. Short Form-36), coping (i.e. Chronic Pain Acceptance Questionnaire, Ways of Coping Questionnaire, Coping Strategies Questionnaire or Coping Response Inventory) and falls (i.e. Frequency of falls or Body self-efficacy) to allow the proposed main analysis.

Measures of central tendency (i.e. mean, median) and dispersion (i.e. standard deviation, standard error, 95% confidence intervals) for each reported outcome of interest will be extracted for all timepoints available in each included study. A mean observation weight will be established for each study based on the inverse variance of the estimates at each time point. Outcomes will be modelled as a function of time using models that take into account the dependence of repeated observations and any non-linearity in the relationship. We are planning subgroup analyses for patient characteristics including sex (i.e., male and female), comorbidities (i.e., diagnosis of at least two health conditions or not) and fall history (i.e., fallers or not, fallers are considered older people reporting at least two falls within a year)(29).

attributes.title: How Virus Names and Frames Affect  Xenophobia, Stigma, and Health Behaviors
attributes.description: Using the current viral pandemic as a case study, an experiment uses four between-subjects conditions to examine the extent to which lay perceptions are impacted by (a) the use of ethnic/geographic (vs. scientific) terms when naming a virus, and the related (b) media focus on the personalized/racialized human (vs. geographic or temporal) spread of the virus.

attributes.title: Relativistic Versus Absolutist Mindsets: Reducing Extremity in Political Partisanship
attributes.description:
We had previously conducted initial work on Relativistic-Absolutist Mindsets (RAM), which aimed to explore how relativistic versus absolutist mindsets influence political extremity (and apolitical issues). 

Our goal in the current study is to understand a context wherein having a relativistic versus absolutist mindset may yield different downstream consequences. In our previous recent research on RAM, relativistic mindsets predict positive outcomes in politics such as increased empathy toward political opponents, less dehumanization, etc, compared to absolutist mindsets. However, the current COVID-19 context allows us to glean important insights into the boundary conditions and contextual variables of when it might not be ideal to be relativistic about scientific knowledge, social distancing, etc. Thus, this provides us a unique opportunity to study this using natural phenomenon and understand people's relativistic-absolutist mindsets for ways we might increase adherence to cooperative efforts in such contexts, like public health.

copyright_holders: Beverly G. Conrique and Kevin R. Binning

q2.value:
We hypothesize that responses to the updated RAM instrument (composed of epistemological/viewpoint, sociological/situational, and moral relativism-absolutism subscales) will look differently when participants are primed with one of the two primes assigned randomly at the beginning of the study (COVID-19 OR U.S. political partisanship prime). We predict that for the COVID-19 prime, moral RAM scores will be the lowest, followed by epistemological RAM scores, followed by sociological RAM scores (lower scores suggest lower relativism and higher absolutism). On the other hand, for the U.S. political partisanship prime, we predict that epistemological RAM scores will be the lowest, followed by moral RAM scores, followed by sociological RAM scores. 
We predict that these scores will also differentially predict reactions to disagreement across the disagreement topics shown to participants (composed of apolitical, taboo, moral, and political examples). In general, higher RAM (higher relativism, lower absolutism) will coincide with less harsh reactions to disagreement (composed of rating those who disagree with oneself as uninformed, irrational, and immoral). Specifically with the moral disagreement topics, higher moral subscale RAM scores (higher relativism, lower absolutism), will be related to utilitarian choices in the moral disagreement topics and less harsh reactions to disagreement; lower moral subscale RAM (lower relativism, higher absolutism) will be related to deontological choices and harsher reactions to disagreement across moral examples. Specifically with the political disagreement topics, higher sociological subscale RAM scores and higher epistemological subscale RAM scores (higher relativism, lower absolutism) will be related to less harsh reactions to disagreement on political examples (compared to lower RAM scores). Epistemological RAM will be the strongest predictor of reactions to disagreement on apolitical disagreement topics, while epistemological, moral, and sociological RAM will be similar predictors of reactions to disagreement on taboo disagreement topics.
Finally, we predict that RAM will show good internal consistency both after conducting factor analyses and item response theory analyses, and will have good discriminant validity compared to other established scales/constructs (i.e., Need for Closure, Perspective-Taking from the IRI Empathy scale, Intellectual Humility).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We have a between subjects design with 1 factor (social issue) with 2 levels (COVID-19 or U.S. political partisanship).

All participants will be presented with a randomized writing prompt. The prompt will read: 
As you may know, the COVID-19 Coronavirus is spreading in many parts of the United States (political partisanship is increasing in many parts of the United States). Americans are highly divided in how dangerous they see the virus for the health of the country (in how dangerous they see this partisanship for the health of the country).
Take a moment to think about your own views about the threat posed by COVID-19 (partisanship), and think for a moment about those who disagree with you. 

Please write briefly about your own views and the views of people who disagree with you on COVID-19 (partisanship).

Before every RAM subscale (sociological, epistemological, moral) section, the instructions will then read: As you complete the items below, please keep your thoughts on COVID-19 (partisanship) in mind. As a reminder, you wrote: [autofilled participants response to writing prompt].

Following the writing prompt, participants will be asked to further elaborate on their choices with any additional thoughts that were not addressed above. This will serve as a way to glean additional thoughts from participants and to also help serve as a manipulation check.

q7.value: Participants will be randomized into one of the two conditions (i.e., COVID-19 or U.S. political partisanship). After this first part of the study where participants will complete the RAM scale, the following sections assessing personal beliefs and reactions to disagreement on apolitical, taboo, moral, and political examples will be randomized within-subjects to decrease order effects.  These conditions will be assigned randomly will be done via Qualtrics.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific. Participants will be paid at the $6.50/hour recommended rate for agreeing to participate in the survey, which will last approximately 20 minutes. Participants must be at least 18 years old to participate. Participants must also be enrolled on Prolific; self-identify as a Democrat or Republican; list their political affiliation as liberal, moderate, or conservative on Prolific; and be US participants.

q11.value: We will attempt to recruit 400 participants.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect small effect sizes at the standard .05 alpha error probability. Arbitrary constraints such as money was also considered.

question.value: We are manipulating which writing prompt participants read at the beginning of the study (either on COVID-19 or U.S. political partisanship).

Participants will be asked to fill out survey items measuring RAM, their personal beliefs on apolitical, political, taboo, and moral topics, and their reactions to disagreement across these topics. Participants will also be asked to complete the Need for Closure (NFC), Intellectual Humility (IH), and Perspective-Taking (PT; subscale from the IRI Empathy scale) instruments.  Following this, participants will be asked demographic information such as political party affiliation, age, gender identity, etc..

We will define three types of RAM, epistemological, sociological, and moral subscale indices, by averaging the scores across the three subtypes. Depending on whether it makes sense to do so, a total RAM score will be calculated (collapsing across types of subscales). Reactions to disagreement will be averaged across the 4 disagreement topics (apolitical, political, taboo, and moral) to create Reaction to Disagreement indices, and these will be further calculated for each type of rating of the person who disagrees with participants (to create 12 perceived immorality/irrationality/uninformed of opposing viewpoint scores across the 4 disagreement topics. Finally, indices will be calculated for NFC, IH, and PT. Further, we will include indices for participants' political ideology and political party, religion, media consumption in order to use them in planned analyses described below.

We will use a bivariate correlations, ANOVA, and OLS regression to analyze our results.  We will conduct analyses to determine whether RAM is a valid and reliable measurement tool using factor analyses and item response theory analyses. We will also explore whether RAM scores differed significantly depending on condition. We will check to see whether significant associations exist between RAM and reactions to disagreement (and whether these further were moderated by condition). We will also explore whether demographics (religion, media consumption, political ideology/party) moderate any of the significant relationships between our RAM and reactions to disagreement. We will also explore whether RAM is a better and unique predictor than other constructs (NFC, IH, PT, political ideology).

q19.value: We will be using an alpha value of .05 as our cutoff criteria. All analyses will be two-tailed.

q20.value: Self-report awareness checks will be included at the end of the survey.

q21.value: If a participant does not complete at least 80% of items for each scale that will be averaged/formed into our composite measures, that participant will not be included in the analysis.
